   Assessment and Plan: This is a 41 y.o. African American Male w/ OSA on
   CPAP, HTN, Asthma p/w fevers, SOB, hemoptysis, transferred to ICU for
   hypoxia, lobar consolidation.
   .
   ##. Hypoxia: Based on initial ABG, large A-a gradient noted. I suspect
   his hypoxia is due to a combination of hypoventilation as well as
   physiological shunt. Given pt's body habitus, h.o. of CPAP use suspect
   pt does have soem obesity hypoventilation syndrome. This coupled with
   his consolidation versus lobar collapse which provides a shunt is
   likely responsible for his A-a gradient and hypoxia. Pt transferred to
   the ICU given his hypoxia, CTA shows no large PE (would suspect large
   PE in case of such hypoxia).
   - will continue to monitor in the ICU
   - Pt cannot remember if was on BiPAP versus CPAP. Will set on autosat
   CPAP for now and monitor O2 sat. If pt continues to have problems with
   saturation will consider BiPAP versus intubation
   - given ?lobar consolidation and hypoxia will expand pt's abx coverage.
   Will d/c Vancoymcin and start on Ceftriaxone with Levofloxacin
   - will continue on Albuterol nebs q2hr PRN
   - will keep NPO overnight
   - check X-ray in the AM
   - will recheck ABG if respiratory status changes
   .
   ##. Hemoptysis: Pt was transferred from floor to ICU given concern of
   hemoptysis and hypoxia. On discussion with the pt hemoptysis has been 1
   tablespoon and occurs with his cough. Given low rate of blood flow
   suspect blood is from pulmonary circulation. On review of CT scan
   appears to be consolidation versus hemorrhage given heterogeneity.
   Hemoptysis likely from PNA, CTA already negative for P. Embolism,
   tumour burden. Although pt has history of Cocaine and Heroin use he
   denies any recent smoking of Cocaine. Pt not recently exposed to anyone
   with TB, has distant history of being in prison.
   - will continue to monitor amount of hemoptysis
   - will consider intubation for airway protection if gross hemoptysis
   - will continue on aforementioned abx Ceftriaxone/Levofloxacin
   - will continue on scheduled Benzonatate
   - will place PPD today
   - will consider possible bronchoscopy when pt's breathing status has
   improved
   .
   ##. Acuite Kidney Injury: Pt's Creatinine on admission elevated at 1.5
   but trending down, likely pre-renal due to increased insensible losses
   from fever.
   - Will monitor UOP
   - trend Creatinine
   .
   ##. HTN: Will continuie on home regimen of Clonidine,
   .
   ##. PSYCH: Pt has h.o. Bipolar d.o., depression, will continue on home
   regimen of Citalopram and Buproprion. Will hold off on Trazadone given
   pt's hypoxia.
   - will restart Trazadone when hypoxia improves
   .
   ##. OSA: Pt not sure if he is on CPAP versus BiPAP at home. Will
   continue on autoset CPAP at this time and advance pending pt's clinical

   .

   .

   .
